# From Data toward information

**Data** is _given._ **Information** is _taken._


- **Data**: Recorded facts.
- **Information**: a particular form of data well suited to communicate with humans and intended to guide conclusions, beliefs, decision, and action.


Footnote: Kaplan. 2011.  https://dtkaplan.github.io/SDS-book/tidy-data.html

# Data

- Your raw data sources 
- Ancillary data

_citeable, archived, transparent_

- Finding it?  Come See CVS

We'll come back to data processes in a moment
---
# _Project Management_ and file structure

- Source code is the _workflow orchestrator_  used to manage project elements
	1. data wrangling 
	2. analysis 
	3. visualization
	4. reporting 
	5. archiving
-  example: file management hierarchical structure
-  example: RStudio IDE with git version control

---
# _Data_:

- Generate and manage data and analysis with code 
- Incorporate found and produced data into the same project
- Data wrangling (normalization & cleaning) as reproducible processes
- Protect personally identifiable information (PRDN)
- Relational database systems bring complexity: great power and administrative responsibility
- example:  tidy data
- example tools:  OpenRefine ; R notebooks ; Python Jupyter notebooks

---
# _Literate Coding Notebooks_  

combine code with prose and visualizations

-  Analysis AND report writing
	- Render reports from code
	- Data code-books are part of the project
	- Reports...

---
# Literate coding, continued...

-  Analysis AND report writing. (CONTINUED)
	- **Reports**: Notebooks can be used to _show the work_ without needing to reproduce the exact compute environment 
	-  _Markdown_
		-  Structure your analysis and documentation
		-  _Reports are derived and rendered_ from notebooks
			- Generate slides, dashboards, documents, visualizations, etc. from the same source code 
			- Static and Interactive documents work well with R Markdown literate coding
	
-  examples: Jupyter Notebooks and R Markdown documents

---
# _Visualizing_ ("graphics") & Spatial Analysis (GIS & Mapping)

-  Use code-based tools 
- example:  grammar of graphics with ggplot2
- example: altair
- example: spatial analysis with the sf package in R

---
# _Archiving_

-  _ Version Control_ (Git) + Social Coding for collaboration & self-documenting the story of your code (i.e. your project.) within a code repository [GitHub | GitLab | BitBucket]
-  Archival _Repositories_ 
	-  disciplinary v institutional
	-  data repositories 
	-  DOIs for output: Article, Code, etc. (i.e. Publishing)
-  _Containers_: computational and archival representations of your project at various publishable milestones
